dataset.title: Climate data from the SINERR/GCE/UGAMI weather station at Marsh Landing on Sapelo Island, Georgia, from 01-Jan-2012 to 31-Dec-2012

associatedParty.organizationName: Sapelo Island National Estuarine Research Reserve
Sapelo Island National Estuarine Research Reserve

abstract.para: Air temperature, relative humidity, barometric pressure, precipitation, photosynthetically-available and total solar radiation, and wind speed and direction were measured using an automated Campbell Scientific Instruments climate station installed at Marsh Landing on Sapelo Island, Georgia. Observations were logged at 15 minute intervals throughout the study period. The sensors were mounted on a 10m aluminum tower, with wind sensors mounted at the top, light sensors at approximately 5m, and other sensors at 2-3m to minimize interference from the surrounding landscape. This climate station was jointly operated by the Sapelo Island National Estuarine Research Reserve, the Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER Project, and University of Georgia Marine Institute.

intellectualRights.para: All publications based on this data set must cite the contributor and Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER project, and two copies of the manuscript must be submitted to the GCE-LTER Information Management Office.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Overall bounding box describing the geographic region within the Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER study domain represented in data set MET-GCEM-1301, based on the maximum geographic extents of all site polygons referenced in the data set

section.title: Climate Measurements
section.para: Sensor readings were taken at 5 second intervals by a Campbell Scientific Instruments CR1000 data logger, and converted from analog voltage to calibrated digital data, if necessary, by the NERR CDMO CR1000 data logger program (i.e. SAPELO_SAPMLMET_060822.CR1). Values and times of minimum and maximum air temperature and maximum wind speed were calculated by the CR1000 program, as well as Standard Error of Wind Direction. Tables of measurements and calculations were then saved as a data table on the CR1000 storage module at 15 minute intervals, and then transmitted hourly via TX312 GOES Satellite telemetry to the NOAA Hydrometeorological Automated Data System (http://www.nws.noaa.gov/oh/hads/).

methodStep.instrumentation: CR1000 Data Logger; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific Instruments (model: CR1000)
Barometric Pressure Sensor; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific Instruments (model: CS105); parameter: Barometric Pressure (accuracy: ±0.5 mb at +20°C, range: 600 to 1060 mb)
Quantum Sensor; manufacturer: LICOR (model: LI190SB); parameter: Photosynthetically-Available Radiation (accuracy: <1% deviation, range: 0 to 10,000 µE/m^2/s)
Rain Gauge; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific Instruments (model: TE525MM); parameter: Precipitation (accuracy: 1% at <10 mm/hr to 5% at 20-30 mm/hr, readability: 0.1 mm, )
Anemometer and Wind Vane; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific Instruments (model: 03001-5 Wind Sentry); parameter: Wind Direction (readability: 0.8 m/s threshold, range: 0 to 360 degrees)
Anemometer and Wind Vane; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific Instruments (model: 03001-5 Wind Sentry); parameter: Wind Speed (accuracy: ±0.5 m/s, range: 0.5 to 50 m/s)
Pyranometer; manufacturer: LICOR (model: LI200X); parameter: Solar Radiation (accuracy: +/-3% typical, +/-5% maximum, range: 0 to 3000 W/m^2 (400-1100nm))
Temperature and Humidity Probe; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific Instruments (model: HMP45C); parameter: Air Temperature (accuracy: 0.2-0.4 C, range: -39.2 to +60 C)
Temperature and Humidity Probe; manufacturer: Campbell Scientific Instruments (model: HMP45C); parameter: Relative Humidity (accuracy: 2%, range: 0-100%)

section.title: Data Acquisition and Processing
section.para: Data arrays were periodically downloaded from the NOAA HADS web site, parsed, quality-checked, documented and archived in the GCE-LTER Information Management office using data retrieval and parsing functions in the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB (http://gce-lter.marsci.uga.edu/public/im/tools/data_toolbox.htm). Negative values of PAR (photosynthetically-available radiation) and total solar radiation, representing dark signal noise, were converted to zeros during data processing.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: GCE Study Site ML -- Marsh Landing, Sapelo Island, Georgia, USA. Marsh landing, where the Georgia DNR ferry docks on its route between the mainland (Meridian) and Sapelo Island.

section.title: Climate Measurements
section.para: Climate observations were collected at 15 minute intervals from a single location using an automated Campbell Scientific Instruments weather station and data logger.

Data from all sensors were collected and logged at 15 minute intervals by an automated Campbell Scientific Instruments data logger (model CR1000). Values and times of minimum and maximum air temperature and maximum wind speed were calculated by the CR1000 program, as well as Standard Error of Wind Direction. Arrays of measurements and calculations were stored as a data table in the CR1000 storage module, and transmitted hourly via TX312 GOES Satellite telemetry to the NOAA Hydrometeorological Automated Data System (http://www.nws.noaa.gov/oh/hads/). Data arrays were then periodically downloaded from the HADS web site, parsed, documented and archived in the GCE-LTER Information Management office.

project.title: Georgia Coastal Ecosystems LTER Project II

abstract.para: The Georgia Coastal Ecosystems (GCE) LTER program, located on the central Georgia coast, was established in 2000. The study domain encompasses three adjacent sounds (Altamaha, Doboy, Sapelo) and includes upland (mainland, barrier islands, marsh hammocks), intertidal (fresh, brackish and salt marsh) and submerged (river, estuary, continental shelf) habitats. Patterns and processes in this complex landscape vary spatially within and between sites, and temporally on multiple scales (tidal, diurnal, seasonal, and interannual). Overlain on this spatial and temporal variation are long-term trends caused by climate change, sea level rise, and human alterations of the landscape. These long-term trends are likely to manifest in many ways, including changes in water quality, river discharge, runoff and tidal inundation patterns throughout the estuarine landscape. The overarching goal of the GCE program is to understand the mechanisms by which variation in the quality, source and amount of both fresh and salt water create temporal and spatial variability in estuarine habitats and processes, in order to predict directional changes that will occur in response to long-term shifts in estuarine salinity patterns.

funding.para: This material is based upon work supported by the National Science Foundation under grant numbers OCE-9982133 and OCE-0620959. Any opinions, findings, conclusions, or recommendations expressed in the material are those of the author(s) and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation.

dataTable.entityDescription: Main data table for data set MET-GCEM-1301

online.onlineDescription: Spreadsheet comma-separated value (CSV) text file with a five line header containing the data set title, column titles, units and column types

description.para: Data file post-processing in the GCE-LTER Information Management Office

abstract.para: The GCE Data Toolbox is a comprehensive library of functions for metadata-based analysis quality control, transformation and management of ecological data sets. The toolbox is based on the GCE Data Structure, a MATLAB specification for storing tabular data along with all information required to interpret the data and generate formatted metadata (documentation). Metadata fields in the structure are queried by toolbox functions for all operations, allowing functions to process and format values appropriately based on the type of information they represent. This semantic processing approach supports highly automated and intelligent data analysis and ensures data set validity throughout all processing steps.

Quality control analysis was performed using the GCE Data Toolbox for MATLAB software. Column data types are validated upon importing the table into MATLAB, and qualifier flags are automatically generated for data values based on QA/QC criteria for each data column pre-defined in metadata templates (e.g. value range checks, sanity checks, pattern checks). Automatically-assigned qualifier flags are reviewed graphically and revised or augmented as deemed appropriate by GCE information management staff, based on metadata information from the contributor, values of other measured variables, or statistical tests. Qualifier flags are also assigned to values that are imputed or derived, revised, or otherwise differ from values in the original data submission. A column of coded qualifier flags is generated and included in the data table if flags are assigned to any value in a data column.
